incomeBrackets.label: Working Poor
incomeBrackets.description: It's a grind. Every dollar is stretched. Focus on essentials for the family.

incomeBrackets.label: Low Income
incomeBrackets.description: Budgeting is an art form. A family night out for pizza is a rare, celebrated event.

incomeBrackets.label: Lower Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Essentials are covered, maybe some family activities. Saving is tough but not impossible.

incomeBrackets.label: Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Comfortable family life, but mindful of spending. Building a nest egg and a 401k.

incomeBrackets.label: Upper Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Family life's pretty good! More treats, less stress. Investments are growing.

incomeBrackets.label: Affluent
incomeBrackets.description: Enjoying finer things with the family. Weekend getaways and nice dinners are regular.

incomeBrackets.label: High Income
incomeBrackets.description: Luxury choices become more accessible for the family. Quality of life upgrades.

incomeBrackets.label: Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Premium experiences are standard. Financial advisor helps manage family wealth.

incomeBrackets.label: Very Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Elite living for the family. Significant choices in education and travel.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra High Net Worth
incomeBrackets.description: Exclusive access and bespoke services. Family hobbies can be extravagant.

incomeBrackets.label: Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Congrats, you made it! Smart allocation and enjoying the fruits with your family.

incomeBrackets.label: Multi-Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Significant financial freedom. Global travel and investment opportunities for the family.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: The world is your family's playground. Legacy planning and philanthropy.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Elite
incomeBrackets.description: Your family's biggest worry? Which continent for the summer. Influencing broader causes.

incomeBrackets.label: Billionaire Class
incomeBrackets.description: Price tags are suggestions. Next stop: shaping global change or funding major family endeavors.

items.title: Home Cooking on a Budget
items.desc: Staples like pasta, rice, beans. Focus on supermarket private labels (e.g., Kroger Value, Tesco Everyday Value). A rare treat: $5 pizza (Little Caesars, Domino's) or local takeaway.
items.financialNote: Food budget is extremely tight, maximizing nutrition per dollar.

items.title: Strategic Grocery Shopping
items.desc: Around 400-500/month per adult at chains like Kroger, Safeway (USA), Tesco, Sainsbury's (UK), Carrefour (EU), Woolworths (AU). Occasional organic produce if on sale.
items.financialNote: Groceries are a significant, planned expense. Balancing quality and cost.

items.title: Regular Foodie Exploration
items.desc: Weekly family dinners at popular local restaurants, food halls, or trying diverse cuisines (e.g., Thai, Mexican, Italian). Maybe craft beers at a local spot for adults.
items.financialNote: Dining out is a regular part of the lifestyle.

items.title: Premium Pantry & Organic Focus
items.desc: 1500+/month on food & wine. Sourcing from specialty butchers, fishmongers, and gourmet stores (e.g., Eataly, Dean & DeLuca style). High-end kitchen appliances from brands like Wolf, Viking, or Miele may be present.
items.financialNote: Home cooking is elevated to a gourmet hobby. Top-tier ingredients and equipment.

items.title: Private Chef & Exclusive Reservations
items.desc: Personal chef for special family occasions or regular meal prep. Securing tables at globally renowned, often hard-to-book establishments (e.g., Noma, The French Laundry, Osteria Francescana).
items.financialNote: Ultimate convenience and exclusivity in dining.

items.title: Curated Wine Cellar & Sommelier Access
items.desc: Building and maintaining a wine cellar with investment-grade wines (e.g., Bordeaux First Growths, Grand Cru Burgundy, cult Napa Cabernets like Screaming Eagle). Potentially engaging a wine consultant or sommelier for acquisitions and cellar management. Wine tourism to renowned regions.
items.financialNote: Wine as a serious hobby and asset class.

items.title: Michelin-Star Private Chef on Staff
items.desc: A full-time private chef, often with experience in Michelin-starred restaurants, manages the family's daily dietary needs, menu planning for events, and provisioning across multiple properties.
items.financialNote: Dining is a managed service, not an activity. The chef is part of the household's professional staff.

items.title: Priority Access to Global Culinary Events
items.desc: Access to any restaurant globally is assumed. Focus shifts to unique culinary experiences: private dinners in museum cellars, bespoke food tours with famous chefs, or buyouts of top restaurants for private family events.
items.financialNote: Experience is curated by the Family Office team to be unique and private.

items.title: Renting in Less Central Areas / Shared Living
items.desc: Renting a smaller apartment or sharing a house in an older building, often further from city centers or amenities. Basic, functional furniture, often second-hand or self-assembled (e.g., basic IKEA, Walmart).
items.financialNote: Rent/housing is the largest expense, often >40-50% of income. Focus on safety and affordability.

items.title: DIY Furnishings & Repairs
items.desc: Furniture from thrift stores, Facebook Marketplace, or hand-me-downs. YouTube tutorials for basic home repairs are essential.
items.financialNote: Furnishing and upkeep rely on resourcefulness, minimal budget.

items.title: Modest Apartment or Starter Condo
items.desc: Renting a 1-2BR apartment in a decent neighborhood. Basic but functional amenities.
items.financialNote: Housing is a primary, manageable expense, typically 30-40% of income.

items.title: Small Starter Home or Larger Rental
items.desc: Owning a small starter home/condo in an area with good public schools, or renting a 2-3BR apartment/townhouse. Focus on space and safety.
items.financialNote: Prioritizing a safe environment and good schools for kids, often at the edge of affordability.

items.title: Practical Furniture (IKEA, Wayfair)
items.desc: Furnishing with new, budget-friendly items from IKEA, Target, Wayfair, or similar. Assembling flat-pack furniture is common.
items.financialNote: Furnishing on a budget, prioritizing functionality and clean aesthetics.

items.title: Comfortable Home Ownership / Quality Rental
items.desc: Owning a modest single-family home, larger apartment/townhome in a good school district or desirable neighborhood. Or, renting a modern apartment with some amenities.
items.financialNote: Managing mortgage, property taxes, HOA fees, or higher rental costs. Typically 25-35% of income.

items.title: Mid-Range Furniture & Decor
items.desc: Upgrading to better quality furniture from stores like West Elm, CB2, Pottery Barn, John Lewis (UK), or Article. Investing in better mattresses, linens, and some decor items.
items.financialNote: Creating a more personalized and comfortable home environment.

items.title: Luxury Home or Upscale Apartment
items.desc: Spacious, well-appointed home in a prime neighborhood, or a luxury condo/apartment with premium amenities (gym, pool, concierge, security) in the city center. Smart home features, high-end finishes.
items.financialNote: Property is a significant asset and reflection of status. Housing costs may be <25% due to higher income, or higher for prime locations.

items.title: Interior Design & High-End Renovations
items.desc: Working with an interior designer for renovations or decor. Custom cabinetry (Poggenpohl, Smallbone), professional-grade appliances (Sub-Zero, Wolf, Gaggenau), and investing in original art or high-quality prints.
items.financialNote: Significant investment in creating a bespoke living space.

items.title: Managed Global Property Portfolio
items.desc: Owning multiple significant properties in key global locations (e.g., London, NYC, St. Barts, Aspen). Each is treated as a managed asset, fully staffed and turnkey, ready for arrival at any time.
items.financialNote: This is a real estate portfolio, managed by the Family Office for diversification and personal use. Focus is on location, security, and quality.

items.title: Custom-Built Architectural Estates
items.desc: Commissioning a world-renowned architect (a 'starchitect') to design a bespoke primary residence or compound. The process is a multi-year project involving significant capital and a team of designers and engineers.
items.financialNote: Creating a unique architectural statement and a primary family seat. It is an asset-creation project.

items.title: Dynastic Compounds & Heritage Properties
items.desc: Ownership of large, historically significant estates, private islands, or custom-built family compounds designed for multi-generational use. These properties are managed like a luxury hotel enterprise.
items.financialNote: These are legacy assets, central to the family's identity and long-term vision. Their operational budget is a significant line item for the Family Office.

items.title: Land Assemblage & Development
items.desc: Strategic acquisition of large parcels of land in desirable areas for conservation, development, or to ensure long-term privacy and security for a primary compound.
items.financialNote: Real estate as a strategic activity for legacy, security, and investment, managed by a dedicated team within the Family Office.

items.title: Public Transit & Walking/Cycling
items.desc: Reliant on local bus, subway/tram, or train systems. Walking and a basic bicycle are primary modes for local travel.
items.financialNote: Transportation costs minimized, focused on fares or basic bike maintenance.

items.title: Older, High-Mileage Car (If Owned)
items.desc: If a car is necessary, it's likely an older (>10 years), high-mileage model. Gas, insurance, and unexpected repairs (e.g., for a Ford Focus, Honda Civic from early 2000s) are major budget concerns.
items.financialNote: Car ownership is a significant, often unpredictable expense.

items.title: Dependable Used Car
items.desc: Owning a reliable used car (e.g., 5-8 year old Toyota Corolla, Honda CR-V, VW Golf). Focus on fuel efficiency and lower maintenance costs. Car payments or savings for replacement are budgeted.
items.financialNote: Car is a tool for commuting and family needs.

items.title: Occasional Ride-Sharing
items.desc: Using Uber/Lyft/Bolt/Grab for specific needs like airport trips, nights out, or when public transit isn't viable.
items.financialNote: Ride-sharing as a supplement, not primary transport.

items.title: New(er) Practical Car or Entry EV
items.desc: A new or certified pre-owned practical family car (e.g., Subaru Outback, Toyota RAV4, Honda CR-V, Kia Telluride, VW Tiguan). Possibly an entry-level EV like a Nissan Leaf or Chevy Bolt if incentives/charging are favorable.
items.financialNote: Managing a car loan and comprehensive insurance. Focus on safety and modern features.

items.title: Worry-Free Maintenance & Insurance
items.desc: Regular dealer servicing for newer car, comprehensive insurance coverage. Less panic over check engine lights; possibly extended warranties.
items.financialNote: Predictable car ownership costs.

items.title: Luxury Daily Driver
items.desc: Driving a new or recent model luxury SUV or sedan (e.g., Tesla Model Y/S, BMW X5/5 Series, Audi Q7/A6, Mercedes-Benz GLE/E-Class, Range Rover Evoque, Porsche Macan).
items.financialNote: Comfort, performance, and brand prestige are important. Depreciation is a known factor.

items.title: Two-Car Household (Practical + Fun)
items.desc: A luxury daily driver plus a second vehicle, which might be another practical car for a spouse, or a 'fun' weekend car (e.g., Mazda MX-5, Ford Mustang, used Porsche Boxster).
items.financialNote: Multiple vehicles for different family needs or hobbies.

items.title: Exotic & Collector Cars
items.desc: Owning high-performance sports cars (Ferrari, Lamborghini, McLaren), ultra-luxury sedans/SUVs (Rolls-Royce, Bentley), or a collection of classic/rare automobiles. Climate-controlled garage is standard.
items.financialNote: Cars as passion assets, investments, or status symbols.

items.title: Private Driver / Chauffeur Service
items.desc: Employing a full-time chauffeur for daily transport in a luxury vehicle (e.g., Mercedes S-Class, Range Rover Autobiography). Alternatively, heavy use of high-end black car services.
items.financialNote: Ultimate convenience and time-saving for transportation.

items.title: Private Aviation (Fractional or Charter)
items.desc: Consistent use of private jets via fractional ownership (e.g., NetJets) or premium charter services (e.g., VistaJet). Commercial aviation is no longer a factor for family travel.
items.financialNote: Transportation is a logistical operation focused on efficiency, privacy, and security. It is managed by the Family Office staff.

items.title: Managed Fleet of Vehicles
items.desc: A curated collection of vehicles is maintained by staff across various properties, ensuring the right car (luxury sedan, SUV, sports car) is always ready. A full-time driver is typically on staff.
items.financialNote: Vehicles are assets managed for specific functions. The chauffeur is part of the security and logistics team.

items.title: Staycations & Local Outings
items.desc: Exploring local parks, free museum days, community events. Annual family camping trip at a state/national park or local campsite using budget gear (e.g., Ozark Trail, Coleman).
items.financialNote: Travel budget is minimal to non-existent. Focus on free/low-cost local activities.

items.title: Road Trip Contributions
items.desc: Chipping in for gas/petrol if a friend or relative with a car is planning a trip to a nearby city, beach, or attraction. Bringing shared snacks.
items.financialNote: Opportunistic travel.

items.title: Budget Domestic Trips
items.desc: Annual family vacation via driving or budget airlines (e.g., Spirit, Ryanair, EasyJet, Southwest). Staying in budget hotels (e.g., Holiday Inn Express, Premier Inn), motels, or basic Airbnb/VRBO rentals.
items.financialNote: Travel is carefully planned and saved for. Focus on affordability.

items.title: Regional Exploration
items.desc: Weekend trips to nearby cities, national parks, or attractions. Camping with better gear, or renting a cabin.
items.financialNote: Exploring accessible destinations.

items.title: Introductory International Travel / Theme Parks
items.desc: First family trips to popular international destinations (e.g., all-inclusive resort in Mexico/Caribbean, a week in a major European city like London or Paris, or a trip to Disney/Universal). Staying in mid-range hotels or well-reviewed Airbnbs.
items.financialNote: Travel is a regular, planned expense. Creating family memories.

items.title: Comfortable Domestic Travel
items.desc: Flying major airlines (e.g., Delta, British Airways, Qantas) for domestic trips. Staying in reputable mid-tier hotels (e.g., Hilton, Marriott, Hyatt Place). Activities like ski trips, beach vacations, or exploring national parks with more comfort.
items.financialNote: Prioritizing convenience and comfort in travel.

items.title: Business Class Travel & Luxury Resorts
items.desc: Flying business class for long-haul international flights (e.g., Emirates, Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific). Staying at 5-star resorts and hotels (e.g., Four Seasons, St. Regis, Ritz-Carlton, Aman Resorts). Considering luxury cruises (e.g., Seabourn, Silversea).
items.financialNote: Travel is a significant leisure investment, focused on premium experiences.

items.title: Experiential & Adventure Travel
items.desc: Tailored family adventures: African safaris (e.g., Singita, &Beyond lodges), exploring Patagonia, cultural immersion in Japan, diving in the Galapagos, bespoke tours. Unique, curated experiences are prioritized.
items.financialNote: Seeking unique and enriching travel experiences.

items.title: Private Aviation as Standard
items.desc: Travel is exclusively via private jet (owned or top-tier fractional/charter), enabling point-to-point travel to smaller airfields, ensuring absolute privacy and security.
items.financialNote: This is a core operational function of the Family Office, focused on maximizing time efficiency and security.

items.title: Bespoke & Inaccessible Experiences
items.desc: Travel is no longer about the destination, but about unique access. Examples: private after-hours tour of the Louvre, chartered scientific expedition to Antarctica, or a week on a fully staffed superyacht.
items.financialNote: The Family Office's network and resources are used to create one-of-a-kind experiences that are not publicly available.

items.title: Owned Aircraft & Superyacht
items.desc: Outright ownership of a long-range private jet (e.g., Gulfstream G700) and/or a superyacht (>50m). These are fully staffed, managed, and operated as private, mobile residences.
items.financialNote: These are significant, complex assets with multi-million dollar annual operating budgets, each managed as a separate business unit within the Family Office.

items.title: Global Exploration & Philanthropic Travel
items.desc: Travel is often integrated with philanthropic work, such as visiting foundation sites in remote locations, or for intellectual pursuits like private archaeological digs or conservation projects.
items.financialNote: Travel is a tool for executing the family's broader strategic goals in business, philanthropy, and legacy.

items.title: Free & Low-Cost Fun
items.desc: Utilizing public libraries (books, DVDs, programs), free local concerts/events, hiking. Streaming via ad-supported tiers (Spotify Free, YouTube, Peacock Free) or shared family accounts.
items.financialNote: Entertainment relies on free or very low-cost community resources.

items.title: DIY & Community Hobbies
items.desc: Drawing, writing, learning from free online resources. Board games or card games with friends and family. Community sports leagues.
items.financialNote: Creativity and social connection over monetary spend.

items.title: Local Events & Streaming Subscriptions
items.desc: Catching a movie at matinee prices, attending local fairs or high school sports. Subscribing to 1-2 basic streaming services (e.g., Netflix Standard with Ads, Disney+ Basic).
items.financialNote: Small, planned entertainment expenses. Balancing cost and enjoyment.

items.title: Family Social Outings
items.desc: Bowling, mini-golf, local amateur theater. Potluck dinners with friends.
items.financialNote: Affordable social activities.

items.title: Major Concerts & Live Sports
items.desc: Attending concerts of popular artists (e.g., Taylor Swift, Ed Sheeran - if lucky with tickets!) or professional sporting events (e.g., MLB, NBA, Premier League) a few times a year. Maybe a local ski pass or theme park annual pass.
items.financialNote: Budgeting for higher-cost entertainment experiences.

items.title: Enhanced Home Entertainment
items.desc: Good quality 4K TV (e.g., TCL, Hisense U-Series), a decent soundbar (e.g., Sonos Ray, Vizio M-Series). Current gaming console (PS5, Xbox Series X). Multiple streaming subscriptions (Netflix Premium, HBO Max/Max, Disney+ Bundle).
items.financialNote: Investing in a comfortable home entertainment setup.

items.title: VIP Experiences & Season Tickets
items.desc: VIP packages for concerts/festivals (e.g., Coachella, Glastonbury). Season tickets (club level) for favorite professional sports teams. Memberships to private social or sports clubs (golf, tennis).
items.financialNote: Premium access and regular attendance at high-demand events.

items.title: High-End Hobbies & Collections
items.desc: Collecting art (attending Art Basel, Frieze), fine wines, luxury watches (Rolex, Omega), or vintage guitars. Golf memberships at exclusive clubs. Attending prestigious international events like the Monaco Grand Prix or Wimbledon.
items.financialNote: Hobbies become significant investments.

items.title: Patronage of the Arts & Culture
items.desc: Entertainment shifts from consumption to patronage. Holding board seats at major museums, theaters, or orchestras. Underwriting new productions or exhibitions.
items.financialNote: A strategic activity to shape culture, build legacy, and engage with a peer group. It is managed via the family's foundation.

items.title: Exclusive Access & Private Events
items.desc: Attending invitation-only events like the Allen & Co. conference, exclusive art fair previews (e.g., Art Basel), or private viewings. Hosting private concerts with major artists at one's own estate.
items.financialNote: Access is curated by the Family Office. The peer network is the primary form of entertainment.

items.title: Investment in Entertainment Assets
items.desc: Direct investment in or acquisition of entertainment properties: part-ownership of a professional sports team, a film production company, or a major music catalog.
items.financialNote: Entertainment as an asset class and a platform for influence, managed by the Family Office's investment team.

items.title: Hosting Global Leaders & Influencers
items.desc: Convening private summits, salons, and charity events at family estates, featuring world leaders, Nobel laureates, and top artists. The social circle becomes a curated global network.
items.financialNote: Leveraging social capital and properties to facilitate high-level discourse and influence, aligning with the family's strategic goals.

items.title: Public School & Library Resources
items.desc: Children attend local public schools. Heavy reliance on public library for books, computers, and educational programs. Free online resources like Khan Academy, YouTube tutorials.
items.financialNote: Education primarily via free public resources. For adults, self-teaching.

items.title: Community Learning
items.desc: Free or low-cost community center classes, adult literacy programs. Skill-swapping with friends or neighbors.
items.financialNote: Focus on accessible learning opportunities.

items.title: Public University (In-State) / Community College
items.desc: Children may attend in-state public universities with aid/loans, or community colleges. Adults might take vocational courses or online certificates (e.g., Google Career Certificates, Coursera specialization for a fee).
items.financialNote: Managing student loan debt is a significant concern. Balancing work and study.

items.title: Trade School & Certifications
items.desc: Focus on practical skills via vocational programs, apprenticeships for trades. Online certifications for specific job skills (e.g., CompTIA for IT).
items.financialNote: Investing in skills for career advancement.

items.title: Choice of Public or Private University (with aid/loans)
items.desc: Children attend well-regarded state universities or private universities if scholarships/aid make it feasible. Adults may pursue an MBA from a state school or reputable online program (e.g., UIUC iMBA, Indiana Kelley Direct). Regular contributions to 529 plans or equivalent education savings.
items.financialNote: Strategic planning for education costs. Paying down student loans while investing for children's future.

items.title: Professional Development & Workshops
items.desc: Investing in ongoing professional development: industry conferences (e.g., local tech meetups, marketing seminars), specialized workshops, LinkedIn Learning, MasterClass subscriptions.
items.financialNote: Continuous learning for career growth.

items.title: Elite Universities & Graduate Programs
items.desc: Children may attend highly selective private universities, Ivy League institutions, or top-tier global universities (e.g., Stanford, MIT, Oxbridge) for undergraduate or graduate studies. This may involve less reliance on loans.
items.financialNote: Education costs are a significant but manageable investment in children's future. For adults, executive MBAs (e.g., Wharton, INSEAD).

items.title: Private Tutoring & Specialized Coaching
items.desc: Hiring private tutors for children (e.g., SAT/ACT prep, subject-specific, via services like Crimson Education or local experts). Executive coaching for adults (e.g., BetterUp). Language immersion programs abroad or specialized skill retreats (e.g., Le Cordon Bleu for culinary enthusiasts).
items.financialNote: Personalized educational support and enrichment.

items.title: Elite Global Education & Bespoke Tutoring
items.desc: Children attend the most prestigious international boarding schools (e.g., Le Rosey, Eton). A team of private tutors and admissions consultants ensures optimal educational pathways.
items.financialNote: Providing the most exclusive and tailored global education is a primary focus for ensuring future success.

items.title: University Endowments & Named Institutions
items.desc: Making transformative, multi-generational philanthropic gifts to universities, resulting in named schools, buildings, or endowed professorships.
items.financialNote: Education as a core component of the family's philanthropic legacy and a tool for shaping institutions.

items.title: Private Tutoring & World-Schooling
items.desc: Employing a full-time team of elite educators to provide a completely customized 'world-schooling' education for children, often involving travel and hands-on learning aligned with family interests.
items.financialNote: Ultimate personalization of education, managed as a core project by the Family Office.

items.title: Funding Research & Academic Centers
items.desc: Establishing and funding entire research centers or academic institutes at major universities that align with the family's intellectual, commercial, or philanthropic interests.
items.financialNote: Directly influencing the direction of academic research and discourse on a global scale. This is a strategic philanthropic investment.

items.title: Public Health Services & ER
items.desc: Reliant on community clinics, public health services, or emergency rooms for urgent care. Health is often reactive, not proactive, due to cost concerns.
items.financialNote: Medical debt is a significant risk.

items.title: Basic Health Insurance
items.desc: Typically have an employer-sponsored or marketplace plan. Managing deductibles and co-pays is a key part of the budget.

items.title: Focus on Children's Health
items.desc: Prioritizing children's check-ups, dental, and vision care, sometimes at the expense of parents' own non-urgent care.

items.title: Good Insurance & Preventative Care
items.desc: Able to afford better health, dental, and vision insurance plans. Focus shifts to regular check-ups and screenings for the whole family.

items.title: Gym Memberships & Fitness Classes
items.desc: Joining a standard gym (e.g., LA Fitness) or participating in local fitness classes. Maybe a Peloton subscription.

items.title: Boutique Fitness & Personal Training
items.desc: Memberships to high-end gyms or specialized studios (e.g., Equinox, Orangetheory). May hire a personal trainer.

items.title: Mental Health & Proactive Wellness
items.desc: Regular therapy, coaching, or subscriptions to wellness apps (Headspace, Calm) are common and destigmatized. Massages and other treatments are regular.

items.title: Concierge Medicine & Top Specialists
items.desc: Retaining top primary care physicians for 24/7 access. The Family Office ensures immediate access to the best medical specialists and surgeons worldwide for any health concern.

items.title: Longevity Science & Health Optimization
items.desc: Engaging with leading longevity clinics and researchers. Access to cutting-edge diagnostics, genetic analysis, and personalized wellness protocols with the goal of extending healthspan.

items.title: Private Medical Staff & On-Site Facilities
items.desc: Having medical professionals on retainer or as part of the full-time staff. May include building private, state-of-the-art medical or fitness facilities within a family compound.
items.financialNote: Health and security are fully integrated. Medical preparedness is an operational priority.

items.title: Funding Medical Research
items.desc: Making strategic philanthropic investments to fund research labs, clinical trials, or entire institutes focused on specific diseases or areas of medical science relevant to the family.
items.financialNote: Aiming to directly accelerate medical breakthroughs, viewing it as a high-impact investment for humanity and legacy.

items.title: DIY Everything
items.desc: Haircuts at home or very cheap barbers. All cleaning, cooking, laundry, basic repairs done by family members. Mending clothes instead of replacing.
items.financialNote: Services self-performed to save money. Time is traded for cost savings.

items.title: Community & Family Support
items.desc: Relying on friends, family, or community groups for childcare, occasional help with moves, or pet-sitting. Bartering skills or services.
items.financialNote: Strong reliance on social support network.

items.title: Basic Maintenance Services
items.desc: Budget haircuts (e.g., Great Clips, local barber). Occasional use of TaskRabbit or a local handyman for a specific repair that's beyond DIY skills. Laundromat if no in-unit laundry.
items.financialNote: Limited use of paid services for essential maintenance.

items.title: Occasional Convenience Services
items.desc: A rare treat of house cleaning (perhaps once or twice a year). Trying a meal kit delivery service (e.g., HelloFresh, Blue Apron) for a short period with a discount offer.
items.financialNote: Convenience services are infrequent splurges.

items.title: Regular Personal Care & Home Help
items.desc: Monthly mid-range salon haircuts/styling (e.g., Toni&Guy, local independent salons). Bi-weekly or monthly house cleaning service. Regular lawn care service. Frequent food delivery (DoorDash, Uber Eats). Occasional dog walker or pet sitter.
items.financialNote: Services to save time and maintain quality of life.

items.title: Gym Membership & Wellness Subscriptions
items.desc: Membership at a nicer gym chain (e.g., LA Fitness, Anytime Fitness) or boutique fitness classes (e.g., F45, Orangetheory, ClassPass). Regular massages or wellness treatments. Subscriptions to wellness apps (e.g., Headspace, Calm, Peloton Digital).
items.financialNote: Investing in health, fitness, and well-being.

items.title: Concierge & Enhanced Personal Services
items.desc: Part-time personal assistant (virtual or in-person). Premium spa treatments and wellness retreats (e.g., Canyon Ranch, Miraval). Personal shopper or stylist services (e.g., Nordstrom Stylist, independent consultants).
items.financialNote: High-touch services for personalized convenience and lifestyle management.

items.title: Comprehensive Household Support
items.desc: Full-time or regular part-time nanny or au pair. Professional landscaping and pool maintenance. Regular dog walker, mobile pet groomer. Private chef for some family meals or dinner parties. Custom tailoring.
items.financialNote: Significant delegation of household tasks to professionals.

items.title: Full Estate Management & Professional Staff
items.desc: Employing a full-time, professional household staff managed by an Estate Manager or Chief of Staff. This includes chefs, nannies, housekeepers, drivers, and security.
items.financialNote: This is a Human Resources function. The household is run like a small luxury hospitality business.

items.title: Elite Global Concierge on Retainer
items.desc: Membership with a top-tier global concierge service (e.g., Quintessentially, Knightsbridge Circle) used by the Family Office as an outsourced team for complex logistics and sourcing rare items.
items.financialNote: A tool for operational efficiency and accessing a global network for any request.

items.title: Dedicated Chief of Staff / Security Detail
items.desc: A Chief of Staff manages all personal and household operations. A full-time, professional security detail provides close protection globally for all family members.
items.financialNote: The family's life is a complex enterprise. Security and logistics are paramount and are managed by dedicated professionals.

items.title: Specialized Consultants on Call
items.desc: Retaining a roster of elite consultants for any need: art advisors, wine sommeliers, aviation lawyers, maritime experts, etc. They are deployed by the Family Office as needed.
items.financialNote: Access to the best expertise in any field is a core operational capability.

items.title: Basic Banking & Survival Mode
items.desc: Focus on immediate needs. May use check-cashing services or rely on basic bank accounts (e.g., Chase Secure Banking, local credit union basic account) with minimal fees. Debt is often high-interest (payday loans, credit cards for essentials). Savings are minimal or for very short-term emergencies. No investments.
items.financialNote: Financial stability is precarious. Often unbanked or underbanked.

items.title: Community Financial Literacy
items.desc: May seek help from community financial literacy programs, non-profit credit counseling (e.g., NFCC), or government assistance programs if eligible.
items.financialNote: Seeking foundational financial knowledge and support.

items.title: Building Emergency Fund & Basic Retirement
items.desc: Goal: 3-6 months of expenses in an emergency fund (e.g., in a high-yield savings account like Ally or Marcus). Starting contributions to employer-sponsored retirement plans (401k, 403b) to get any employer match, or opening a Roth IRA (e.g., with Vanguard, Fidelity, Schwab). Initial investments in simple, low-cost target-date funds or broad market index ETFs (e.g., VTI, IXUS).
items.financialNote: Laying the groundwork for financial security.

items.title: Debt Management & Budgeting Tools
items.desc: Actively working to pay down high-interest debt (credit cards, personal loans) using strategies like debt snowball or avalanche. Utilizing budgeting apps (e.g., YNAB, Mint, Personal Capital) and learning about compound interest and long-term planning via blogs/podcasts (e.g., The Ramsey Show, ChooseFI).
items.financialNote: Taking control of debt and cash flow.

items.title: Maxing Retirement Accounts & Diversification
items.desc: Aiming to max out tax-advantaged retirement accounts (401k, Roth IRA, HSA if applicable). Building a diversified portfolio in taxable brokerage accounts with low-cost index funds/ETFs covering US large/small cap, international stocks, and bonds (e.g., Boglehead three-fund portfolio). Asset allocation is a conscious decision.
items.financialNote: Systematic wealth accumulation phase.

items.title: Robo-Advisors & Goal-Based Savings
items.desc: May use robo-advisors (e.g., Betterment, Wealthfront, Schwab Intelligent Portfolios) for automated investment management and tax-loss harvesting. Saving for specific goals like a house down payment, children's education (529 plans). Understanding of investment fees and tax implications grows.
items.financialNote: Leveraging technology for investment management.

items.title: Comprehensive Financial Planning
items.desc: Portfolio likely $500K - $2.5M+. Engage a fee-only Certified Financial Planner (CFP) or wealth advisor for holistic advice. Focus on tax optimization, diversified public market investments, robust insurance coverage (life, disability, umbrella), and foundational estate planning (wills, powers of attorney).
items.financialNote: Professional guidance for growing wealth and managing complexity.

items.title: Accredited Investor Opportunities
items.desc: Beginning to qualify as an accredited investor, gaining access to a broader range of investments like REITs, private real estate syndications (e.g., via platforms like CrowdStreet or RealCrowd, if criteria met), or angel investment groups. Understanding and managing higher risk is key.
items.financialNote: Expanding investment horizons beyond public markets.

items.title: Private Banking & Alternative Investments
items.desc: Working with a dedicated team at a major private bank (e.g., J.P. Morgan Private Bank, Goldman Sachs PWM). Gaining access to alternative investments like hedge funds, private equity, and structured notes.
items.financialNote: Wealth management is sophisticated, focusing on risk management, tax efficiency, and sourcing institutional-quality investments.

items.title: Family Office Services (Multi-Family Office)
items.desc: Utilizing a Multi-Family Office (MFO) to manage the entire family balance sheet, including investments, tax/legal coordination, and philanthropic planning.
items.financialNote: Holistic management of significant, complex wealth by an external team of dedicated professionals.

items.title: Single-Family Office (SFO) Operations
items.desc: Establishing a dedicated legal entity‚Äîa Single-Family Office‚Äîthat acts as the family's private wealth management firm. Hires a CIO, CFO, and legal counsel.
items.financialNote: This is the creation of a private financial enterprise. The focus is direct investing, capital allocation, and enterprise management.

items.title: Direct Investing & Co-Investing
items.desc: The SFO actively sources and executes direct investments in private companies (venture capital, private equity) and real estate, often co-investing alongside major institutional funds.
items.financialNote: Moving from a passive investor to an active capital allocator, seeking to generate alpha through direct market engagement.
